bibl.title: Letter from Henry Rose Carter's secretary to Oliver G. Ricketson, Jr., January 4, 1921

div1.p: Ricketson is not to enter any yellow fever district until ten days after last vaccine injection.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter's secretary to Oliver G. Ricketson, Jr., January 4, 1921
div1.opener:
Noguchi (vaccine)
Ricketson
2121 California St., N. W.
Washington, D. C.
January 4, 1921.
Mr. Oliver G. Ricketson, Jr.,
Fernandina, Fla.
Dear Mr. Ricketson:
div1.p:
In addition to the information sent you this morning with
the Leptospira icteroides vaccine, Dr. Carter asks me to inform
you that Dr. Noguchi says that you should not go into any district
infected with yellow fever until at least ten days have elapsed
since the last injection. Also, that, of course, every known pre-
caution should be taken in addition to prevent your being exposed
to the disease--mosquito nets, etc. as usual--as much so as though
you had had no vaccination.

The vaccine, of course, should be kept in a refrigerator or
other very cool place--though not exposed to cold extreme enough
to freeze it solid.

With best wishes from Dr. Carter, Dr. Noguchi and myself for
the safety and success of the expedition,
div1.closer:
Respectfully yours, Secretary. Assistant Surgeon General H. R. Carter,
2121 California St., N. W. Washington, D. C.
